title: How to Make Pan Dulce

steps.headline: Combine the yeast and warm water.
steps.description: Add ½ cup (118 ml) of warm water to a large bowl, and sprinkle 1 packet (¼ ounce/7 g) of active dry yeast over it. Stir the two together to just combine them.

steps.headline: Let the mixture sit for 10 minutes.
steps.description: It’s important to proof the yeast to ensure that it’s alive and active. Allow the water and yeast mixture to sit, and then check it for bubbles. If there are bubbles, the yeast is ready to go.

steps.headline: Mix in the evaporated milk, sugar, melted butter, egg, and salt.
steps.description: After you’ve proofed the yeast, add ½ cup warm (118 ml) of evaporated milk, ⅓ cup (67 g) of sugar, ⅓ cup (76 g) of butter that’s been melted, 1 egg, and 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt to the bowl. Stir well to ensure that all of the ingredients are fully combined.

steps.headline: Gradually add the flour and cinnamon.
steps.description: Once all of the wet ingredients are combined, mix in 2 cups (250 g) of flour into the bowl until it is incorporated. Add another 2 cups (250 g) of flour and ½ teaspoon (1 g) of ground cinnamon, and stir until the ingredients are blended and a soft dough forms. The easiest way to melt butter is in the microwave. Place it in a microwave-safe bowl and heat it on high in 10 second intervals, stirring after each until it's completely melted. You can also melt the butter in a pan on the stove. Heat it over medium-low heat, stirring frequently until it's completely melted.

steps.headline: Lightly flour your work surface.
steps.description: To keep the dough from sticking, sprinkle your countertop or cutting board with some flour. Spread it around to ensure that the entire surface is dusted. Make sure to flour your hands as well to make working the dough easier. If you prefer, you can butter your work surface  and hands to prevent the dough from sticking rather than flouring it. Dab some butter that's softened to room temperature on a paper towel and wipe it over the surface and your hands.

steps.headline: Knead the dough for several minutes.
steps.description: Remove the dough from the bowl, and place it on your work surface. Use clean hands to knead the dough for 3 to 5 minutes, or until it becomes smooth and supple.

steps.headline: Shape the dough into a ball and place it in a greased bowl.
steps.description: Don’t overwork the dough, but gently press it into a round shape. Butter the inside of a large bowl, and then place the dough ball inside. Turn the dough over a couple of times to lightly coat its surface with the butter.

steps.headline: Cover the bowl and let the dough rise until it doubles in size.
steps.description: Place a clean, damp kitchen towel over the top of the bowl to protect the dough from the air. Allow the dough to rise until it doubles in volume, which should take about an hour.

steps.headline: Beat the softened butter until light and fluffy.
steps.description: Add ½ cup (113 g) of softened butter to a medium bowl. Use an electric mixer on medium speed to cream the butter for 30 seconds until it has a light texture. To soften the butter, measure it out and place it in a bowl. Set it out on the counter at room temperature and allow it to sit for about 30 minutes. You can also use a stand mixer to beat the butter.

steps.headline: Mix in the sugar.
steps.description: Once the butter is light and fluffy, add ⅔ cup (150 g) of sugar to the bowl. Beat the mixture on medium until the sugar is fully incorporated, which should take 30 seconds to a minute.

steps.headline: Stir in some flour, cinnamon, and vanilla.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (125 g) of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons (4 g) of ground cinnamon, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract to the bowl. Mix on low until all of the ingredients are fully combined. Set the topping aside for the moment.

steps.headline: Punch down the dough.
steps.description: You want to remove some of the air from the dough, so use clean hands to gently beat it down. You don’t want to overwork the dough, though -- only punch it down until it’s roughly its original size. The dough shouldn't stick to your hands, but if it feels sticky, you can lightly dust your hands with flour first.

steps.headline: Recover the dough and let it sit for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Place the damp kitchen towel back on top of the bowl. Allow the dough to rest for another few minutes before shaping it.

steps.headline: Divide the dough into 12 pieces.
steps.description: Using clean hands, break the dough into 12 equally sized pieces. Next, roll each piece into a ball.

steps.headline: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place the dough on it.
steps.description: To prevent the rolls from sticking to the baking sheet, place a piece of parchment paper on it. Set the rolls on top of the paper, making sure to space them about 3-inches (7.6-cm) apart. Depending on how large your baking sheet is, you may need more than one. You can grease the sheet with butter if you don’t have any parchment paper.

steps.headline: Divide the topping into 12 balls and flatten them.
steps.description: The topping will have a thick paste-like consistency, so use clean hands to separate it into 12 equally sized balls. Press down on the balls with the palm of your hand to flatten them until they're approximately ⅛- to ¼-inch thick (3- to 6-mm) thick.

steps.headline: Place one piece of topping on each dough ball.
steps.description: Set one of the flattened topping pieces on top of each roll on the baking sheet. Press the topping down onto the dough lightly to secure it in place. The topping and dough should align, but if the topping is slightly larger, press it down over the sides of the dough.

steps.headline: Cut grooves into the topping.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife, such as a paring knife, to lightly score the topping. You can create simple curved lines or a crisscross design, depending on your preference.

steps.headline: Cover the rolls again and let them rise until they double in size.
steps.description: Once the topping is in place and scored, place a clean, damp kitchen towel over the baking sheet to cover the rolls. Allow them to rise for about 40 minutes.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description:
Just before the rolls are finished rising, set the oven temperature to 350°F (180°C). Allow the oven to fully heat, so it’s warm enough to bake the rolls. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/eb\/Make-Pan-Dulce-Step-20.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/eb\/Make-Pan-Dulce-Step-20.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Bake the rolls until they’re golden brown.
steps.description: When the rolls are finished rising, place them in the preheat oven. Let them bake for 15 to 20 minutes, or until they are a light golden brown.

steps.headline: Cool the rolls on wire racks before serving.
steps.description: Once the rolls are finished baking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Use a spatula to lift the rolls off the sheet and onto a wire cooling rack. Allow them to cool for about 3 to 5 minutes, so they’re still warm when you serve them. Store any leftover pan dulce in an airtight container at room temperature. They should stay fresh for about 3 days.

text:
Preparing the Dough Combine the yeast and warm water. Add ½ cup (118 ml) of warm water to a large bowl, and sprinkle 1 packet (¼ ounce/7 g) of active dry yeast over it. Stir the two together to just combine them. Let the mixture sit for 10 minutes. It’s important to proof the yeast to ensure that it’s alive and active. Allow the water and yeast mixture to sit, and then check it for bubbles. If there are bubbles, the yeast is ready to go. Mix in the evaporated milk, sugar, melted butter, egg, and salt. After you’ve proofed the yeast, add ½ cup warm (118 ml) of evaporated milk, ⅓ cup (67 g) of sugar, ⅓ cup (76 g) of butter that’s been melted, 1 egg, and 1 teaspoon (6 g) of salt to the bowl. Stir well to ensure that all of the ingredients are fully combined. Gradually add the flour and cinnamon. Once all of the wet ingredients are combined, mix in 2 cups (250 g) of flour into the bowl until it is incorporated. Add another 2 cups (250 g) of flour and ½ teaspoon (1 g) of ground cinnamon, and stir until the ingredients are blended and a soft dough forms. The easiest way to melt butter is in the microwave. Place it in a microwave-safe bowl and heat it on high in 10 second intervals, stirring after each until it's completely melted. You can also melt the butter in a pan on the stove. Heat it over medium-low heat, stirring frequently until it's completely melted. Kneading and Rising the Dough Lightly flour your work surface. To keep the dough from sticking, sprinkle your countertop or cutting board with some flour. Spread it around to ensure that the entire surface is dusted. Make sure to flour your hands as well to make working the dough easier. If you prefer, you can butter your work surface and hands to prevent the dough from sticking rather than flouring it. Dab some butter that's softened to room temperature on a paper towel and wipe it over the surface and your hands. Knead the dough for several minutes. Remove the dough from the bowl, and place it on your work surface. Use clean hands to knead the dough for 3 to 5 minutes, or until it becomes smooth and supple. Shape the dough into a ball and place it in a greased bowl. Don’t overwork the dough, but gently press it into a round shape. Butter the inside of a large bowl, and then place the dough ball inside. Turn the dough over a couple of times to lightly coat its surface with the butter. Cover the bowl and let the dough rise until it doubles in size. Place a clean, damp kitchen towel over the top of the bowl to protect the dough from the air. Allow the dough to rise until it doubles in volume, which should take about an hour. Mixing Up the Topping Beat the softened butter until light and fluffy. Add ½ cup (113 g) of softened butter to a medium bowl. Use an electric mixer on medium speed to cream the butter for 30 seconds until it has a light texture. To soften the butter, measure it out and place it in a bowl. Set it out on the counter at room temperature and allow it to sit for about 30 minutes. You can also use a stand mixer to beat the butter. Mix in the sugar. Once the butter is light and fluffy, add ⅔ cup (150 g) of sugar to the bowl. Beat the mixture on medium until the sugar is fully incorporated, which should take 30 seconds to a minute. Stir in some flour, cinnamon, and vanilla. Add 1 cup (125 g) of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons (4 g) of ground cinnamon, and 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract to the bowl. Mix on low until all of the ingredients are fully combined. Set the topping aside for the moment. Forming the Rolls Punch down the dough. You want to remove some of the air from the dough, so use clean hands to gently beat it down. You don’t want to overwork the dough, though -- only punch it down until it’s roughly its original size. The dough shouldn't stick to your hands, but if it feels sticky, you can lightly dust your hands with flour first. Recover the dough and let it sit for 10 minutes. Place the damp kitchen towel back on top of the bowl. Allow the dough to rest for another few minutes before shaping it. Divide the dough into 12 pieces. Using clean hands, break the dough into 12 equally sized pieces. Next, roll each piece into a ball. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper and place the dough on it. To prevent the rolls from sticking to the baking sheet, place a piece of parchment paper on it. Set the rolls on top of the paper, making sure to space them about 3-inches (7.6-cm) apart. Depending on how large your baking sheet is, you may need more than one. You can grease the sheet with butter if you don’t have any parchment paper. Topping the Rolls Divide the topping into 12 balls and flatten them. The topping will have a thick paste-like consistency, so use clean hands to separate it into 12 equally sized balls. Press down on the balls with the palm of your hand to flatten them until they're approximately ⅛- to ¼-inch thick (3- to 6-mm) thick. Place one piece of topping on each dough ball. Set one of the flattened topping pieces on top of each roll on the baking sheet. Press the topping down onto the dough lightly to secure it in place. The topping and dough should align, but if the topping is slightly larger, press it down over the sides of the dough. Cut grooves into the topping. Use a sharp knife, such as a paring knife, to lightly score the topping. You can create simple curved lines or a crisscross design, depending on your preference. Cover the rolls again and let them rise until they double in size. Once the topping is in place and scored, place a clean, damp kitchen towel over the baking sheet to cover the rolls. Allow them to rise for about 40 minutes. Baking the Rolls Preheat the oven. Just before the rolls are finished rising, set the oven temperature to 350°F (180°C). Allow the oven to fully heat, so it’s warm enough to bake the rolls. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/eb\/Make-Pan-Dulce-Step-20.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/eb\/Make-Pan-Dulce-Step-20.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake the rolls until they’re golden brown. When the rolls are finished rising, place them in the preheat oven. Let them bake for 15 to 20 minutes, or until they are a light golden brown. Cool the rolls on wire racks before serving. Once the rolls are finished baking, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Use a spatula to lift the rolls off the sheet and onto a wire cooling rack. Allow them to cool for about 3 to 5 minutes, so they’re still warm when you serve them. Store any leftover pan dulce in an airtight container at room temperature. They should stay fresh for about 3 days.
